results.title: The One-Handed Backhand Is on the Way to Extinction
results.abstract: How can something so beautiful to watch, a stroke so etched into tennis history, be so exploitable — and why have a dwindling handful of players remained loyal to it?

media.caption: As the second round wore down on Thursday, Stan Wawrinka stood among the few remaining standard-bearers of the one-handed backhand.

results.title: Tourists Were Told to Avoid Maui. Many Workers Want Them Back.
results.abstract: A plunge in tourism after a disastrous fire has already crippled the economy in Maui. Now, some locals who wanted visitors to stay away are urging them back.

media.caption: Nearly a month after the fire, Maui, a tourism-dependent island with a hotel room for every seven and a half households, is hosting fewer visitors than at any point since the coronavirus pandemic.
media.copyright: Bailey Rebecca Roberts for The New York Times

results.title: A Time Capsule Appeared to Be Full of Dirt. Then, They Looked Closer.
results.abstract: The nearly 200-year-old capsule appeared to contain little of value when it was unveiled Monday during a livestream from the U.S. Military Academy. An archaeologist later found six coins and a medal inside.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: Officials at the U.S. Military Academy prepare to open and unveil the contents of a nearly 200-year-old time capsule during a ceremony at West Point, N.Y., on Monday.

results.title: Investigators Seize ‘Marcus Aurelius’ Statue From Cleveland Museum
results.abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office said the headless bronze, valued at $20 million, is a depiction of the Roman emperor and was looted from Turkey.

media.caption: The Cleveland Museum of Art acquired the bronze statue in 1986. The museum is now calling it “Draped Male Figure” on its website, but had earlier referred to it as a depiction of Marcus Aurelius.

results.title: Mohamed al-Fayed, Tycoon Whose Son Died With Diana, Is Dead at 94
results.abstract: An Egyptian businessman, he built an empire of trophy properties in London, Paris and elsewhere, but it was all overshadowed by a fatal car crash that stunned the world.

media.caption: Mohamed al-Fayed in 2003 outside the Court of Session in Edinburgh, where a judge was asked to consider whether the car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and his son Dodi, was caused deliberately.
